usecase_1: Rule C-17.1 'Vehicle Owner' has the right to request the 'Automaker' to erase 'Vehicle Telemetry Data' concerning them without undue delay, and the 'Automaker' is obligated to erase such data without undue delay for any of the following reasons: a) The 'Vehicle Telemetry Data' is no longer necessary for the purposes for which it was collected or otherwise processed for 'predictive maintenance services'; b) The 'Vehicle Owner' withdraws consent according to Rule C-6.1(a), and there is no other contractual basis for processing the data. Rule C-6.1 Data processing is considered compliant only if at least one of the following applies: a) The 'Vehicle Owner' consents to the processing of their 'Vehicle Telemetry Data' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'predictive maintenance services').
usecase_2: Health Data Space Policy 17.1 'Patient' has the right to request the 'Research Institution' to erase 'Clinical Trial Data' concerning them without undue delay, and the 'Research Institution' is obligated to erase such data without undue delay for any of the following reasons: a) The 'Clinical Trial Data' is no longer necessary for the purposes for which it was collected or otherwise processed for 'drug efficacy analysis'; b) The 'Patient' withdraws their explicit consent according to Policy 6.1(a), and there is no other legal authorization for conducting the research. Policy 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: a) The 'Patient' has given explicit consent to the processing of their 'Clinical Trial Data' for one or more specified research purposes.
usecase_3: Smart Grid Protocol 17.1 'Energy Consumer' has the right to request the 'Grid Operator' to erase 'Smart Meter Readings' concerning them without undue delay, and the 'Grid Operator' is obligated to erase such data without undue delay for any of the following reasons: a) The 'Smart Meter Readings' are no longer necessary for the purposes for which they were collected or otherwise processed for 'load balancing forecasts'; b) The 'Energy Consumer' withdraws consent according to Protocol 6.1(a), and there is no other legal basis for providing the service. Protocol 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if at least one of the following applies: a) The 'Energy Consumer' consents to the processing of their 'Smart Meter Readings' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'load balancing forecasts').
usecase_4: Logistics Data Alliance Charter, Article 17.1 'Cargo Shipper' has the right to request the 'Carrier' to erase 'Shipment Tracking Records' concerning them without undue delay, and the 'Carrier' is obligated to erase such data without undue delay for any of the following reasons: a) The 'Shipment Tracking Records' are no longer necessary for the purposes for which they were collected or otherwise processed for 'supply chain optimization'; b) The 'Cargo Shipper' withdraws consent according to Charter Article 6.1(a), and there are no other transport contract requirements. Charter Article 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if at least one of the following applies: a) The 'Cargo Shipper' consents to the processing of their 'Shipment Tracking Records' for one or more specific purposes.
usecase_5: Federated Learning Network Guideline 17.A 'Data Contributor' has the right to request the 'Model Coordinator' to erase the 'Local Dataset' related to them without undue delay, and the 'Model Coordinator' is obligated to erase such data without undue delay for any of the following reasons: a) The 'Local Dataset' is no longer necessary for the purpose of 'federated model training' for which it was collected; b) The 'Data Contributor' withdraws their participation license according to Guideline 6.A(1), and no other research protocol terms for processing the data exist. Guideline 6.A Processing shall be lawful only if at least one of the following applies: 1) The 'Data Contributor' consents to the processing of their 'Local Dataset' for one or more specific 'federated model training' tasks.
usecase_6: Clinical Trial Data Space Policy, Article 13 When obtaining 'genetic data', the 'Research Institution' shall, where necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing, provide the 'Patient' with the following information: a) The retention period for the 'genetic data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; b) Information on the 'Data Committee' qualified to handle 'Patient' rights requests, which can access, rectify, erase, or restrict rights to the 'genetic data'; c) If processing is based on Policy Article 9.2(A), the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal. Policy Article 9.1 Processing of 'genetic data' revealing 'genetic predispositions' or 'biomarkers' shall be prohibited. 2. Paragraph 1 shall not apply if: a) The 'Patient' has given explicit consent to the processing of such 'genetic data' for one or more specified research purposes, except where the prohibitions referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Patient' under the ethical rules of the 'Data Space'.
usecase_7: Smart City Security Network Regulation, Article 13 When obtaining 'facial recognition data', the 'Network Operator' shall, where necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing, provide the 'Citizen' with the following information: a) The storage period for the 'facial recognition data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; b) Information on the 'City Data Authority' qualified to handle 'Citizen' rights requests, which can access, rectify, erase, or restrict rights to personal information; c) If processing is based on Regulation Article 9.2(A), the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal. Regulation Article 9.1 Processing of 'facial recognition data' revealing 'movement patterns' or 'social connections' shall be prohibited. 2. Paragraph 1 shall not apply if: a) The 'Citizen' has given explicit consent to the processing of such 'facial recognition data' for one or more specified security purposes, except where the prohibitions referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Citizen' under the 'City Public Safety Act'.
usecase_8: Financial Anti-Fraud Alliance Protocol 13 When obtaining 'transactional behavior data', an 'Alliance Member Bank' shall, where necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing, provide the 'Customer' with the following information: a) The retention phase for the 'transactional behavior data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that phase; b) Information on the 'Alliance Data Governance Committee' qualified to handle 'Customer' rights requests, which can access, rectify, erase, or restrict rights to the 'transactional behavior data'; c) If processing is based on Protocol 9.2.A, the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal. Protocol 9.1 Processing of 'transactional behavior data' revealing 'spending habits', 'credit risk levels', or 'political donations' shall be prohibited. 2. Paragraph 1 shall not apply if: a) The 'Customer' has given explicit consent to the processing of such 'transactional behavior data' for one or more specified anti-fraud purposes, except where the prohibitions referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Customer' under 'financial regulatory laws'.
usecase_9: Smart Agriculture Cooperative Charter, Article 13 When obtaining 'soil sensor data', the 'Cooperative' shall, where necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing, provide the 'Farmer' with the following information: a) The storage period for the 'soil sensor data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; b) Information on the 'Data Management Committee' qualified to handle 'Farmer' rights requests, which can access, rectify, erase, or restrict rights to the 'soil sensor data'; c) If processing is based on Charter Article 9.2(A), the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal. Charter Article 9.1 Processing of 'soil sensor data' and 'drone imagery data' revealing 'crop yields', 'pesticide usage', or 'farm financial status' shall be prohibited. 2. Paragraph 1 shall not apply if: a) The 'Farmer' has given explicit consent to the processing of such data for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'precision irrigation'), except where the prohibitions referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Farmer' under the 'Agricultural Data Security Act'.
usecase_10: Autonomous Vehicle Test Zone Regulation, Article 13 When obtaining 'vehicle sensor data', the 'Test Vehicle Operator' shall, where necessary to ensure fair and transparent processing, provide the 'Test Participant' with the following information: a) The storage period for the 'vehicle sensor data', or if that is not possible, the criteria used to determine that period; b) Information on the 'Test Zone Data Supervisory Authority' qualified to handle 'Test Participant' rights requests, which can access, rectify, erase, or restrict rights to the 'vehicle sensor data'; c) If processing is based on Regulation Article 9.2(A), the right to withdraw consent at any time, without affecting the lawfulness of processing based on consent before its withdrawal. Regulation Article 9.1 Processing of 'vehicle sensor data' revealing 'driver behavior patterns' or 'precise vehicle location history' shall be prohibited. 2. Paragraph 1 shall not apply if: a) The 'Test Participant' has given explicit consent to the processing of such 'vehicle sensor data' for one or more specified R&D purposes, except where the prohibitions referred to in paragraph 1 may not be lifted by the 'Test Participant' under the 'National Intelligent Connected Vehicle Test Regulations'.
usecase_11: FinTech Data Space Protocol 20.1 The 'User' has the right to receive their 'personal transaction records' provided to a 'Wealth Management App' in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format, and has the right to transmit those data to another 'Payment Service Provider' without hindrance from the 'Wealth Management App' to which the personal data have been provided, where: a) processing is based on consent pursuant to Protocol 6.1(a); and b) the processing is carried out by automated API interfaces. Protocol 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: a) the 'User' has given consent to the processing of their 'personal transaction records' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'asset allocation analysis'); b) processing is necessary for the performance of an 'investment advisory service contract' to which the 'User' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'User' prior to entering into a contract.
usecase_12: Smart Home Platform Terms of Service, Article 20.1 The 'Homeowner' has the right to receive their 'device usage logs' provided to the 'Platform Operator' in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format, and has the right to transmit those data to another 'Smart Home System' without hindrance from the 'Platform Operator', where: a) processing is based on consent pursuant to Terms of Service Article 6.1(a); and b) the processing is carried out by automated means. Terms of Service Article 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: a) the 'Homeowner' has given consent to the processing of their 'device usage logs' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'home energy optimization'); b) processing is necessary for the performance of a 'security monitoring service contract' to which the 'Homeowner' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'Homeowner' prior to entering into a contract.
usecase_13: Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) Platform Rules 20.1 The 'Passenger' has the right to receive their 'travel history data' provided to the 'MaaS Operator' in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format, and has the right to transmit those data to another 'Urban Traffic Data Platform' without hindrance from the 'MaaS Operator', where: a) processing is based on consent pursuant to Rule 6.1(a); and b) the processing is carried out by automated means. Rule 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: a) the 'Passenger' has given consent to the processing of their 'travel history data' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'personalized route recommendations'); b) processing is necessary for the performance of a 'monthly subscription contract' to which the 'Passenger' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'Passenger' prior to entering into a contract.
usecase_14: Digital Education Portfolio Standard E-20.1 The 'Student' has the right to receive their 'learning process data' provided to the 'School' in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format, and has the right to transmit those data to another 'Higher Education Institution' without hindrance from the 'School', where: a) processing is based on consent pursuant to Standard E-6.1(a); and b) the processing is carried out by automated means. Standard E-6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: a) the 'Student' has given consent to the processing of their 'learning process data' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'academic capability assessment'); b) processing is necessary for the performance of an 'online course agreement' to which the 'Student' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'Student' prior to entering into an agreement.
usecase_15: Industrial IoT (IIoT) Data Sharing Framework, Article 20.1 The 'Equipment Owner' has the right to receive their 'production line sensor data' provided to the 'Factory Operator' in a structured, commonly used, and machine-readable format, and has the right to transmit those data to another 'Supply Chain Partner' without hindrance from the 'Factory Operator', where: a) processing is based on consent pursuant to Framework Article 6.1(a); and b) the processing is carried out by automated means. Framework Article 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: a) the 'Equipment Owner' has given consent to the processing of their 'production line sensor data' for one or more specific purposes (e.g., 'equipment failure prediction'); b) processing is necessary for the performance of a 'maintenance service contract' to which the 'Equipment Owner' is party or in order to take steps at the request of the 'Equipment Owner' prior to entering into a contract.
usecase_16: Catena-X Network Usage Policy 21.1 The 'Supplier' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of 'component carbon footprint data' concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Policy 6.1, including traceability analysis based on those provisions. The 'OEM' shall no longer process the data unless the 'OEM' demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the commercial interests, rights and freedoms of the 'Supplier' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal supply chain claims. Policy 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of a 'sustainable supply chain' or in the exercise of official authority vested in the 'OEM' as an industry leader; f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'OEM' or by a 'third-party regulator' (e.g., 'ESG compliance'), except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'Supplier' which require protection of 'component carbon footprint data'. That shall not apply to processing carried out by public authorities in the performance of their tasks.
usecase_17: Smart Health Data Space Charter 21.1 The 'Patient' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of 'electronic health records' concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Charter 6.1, including cohort study analysis based on those provisions. The 'Research Institution' shall no longer process the personal data unless the 'Research Institution' demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the privacy, rights and freedoms of the 'Patient' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal medical research claims. Charter 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of 'public health surveillance' or in the exercise of official public health authority vested in the 'Research Institution'; f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'Research Institution' or by a 'pharmaceutical regulatory agency' (e.g., 'new drug development'), except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'Patient' which require protection of 'electronic health records', in particular where the 'Patient' is a child. That shall not apply to processing carried out by public authorities in the performance of their tasks.
usecase_18: Intelligent Transport Systems (ITS) Data Sharing Protocol, Article 21.1 The 'Driver' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of 'vehicle trajectory data' concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Protocol 6.1, including traffic flow modeling based on those provisions. The 'Traffic Management Authority' shall no longer process the data unless the 'Traffic Management Authority' demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the privacy, rights and freedoms of the 'Driver' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal urban planning proposals. Protocol 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of 'urban congestion management' or in the exercise of official authority vested in the 'Traffic Management Authority'; f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'Traffic Management Authority' or by a 'third-party navigation service provider' (e.g., 'optimizing traffic signal timing'), except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'Driver' which require protection of 'vehicle trajectory data'. That shall not apply to processing carried out by public authorities in the performance of their tasks.
usecase_19: Energy Data Space Framework 21.A The 'Household User' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of 'electricity consumption pattern data' concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Framework 6.A, including demand response analysis based on those provisions. The 'Grid Company' shall no longer process the data unless the 'Grid Company' demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the 'Household User' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal grid stability claims. Framework 6.A Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of 'securing energy supply' or in the exercise of official utility authority vested in the 'Grid Company'; f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'Grid Company' or by a 'third-party energy service provider' (e.g., 'promoting energy-saving measures'), except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'Household User' which require protection of 'electricity consumption pattern data'. That shall not apply to processing carried out by public authorities in the performance of their tasks.
usecase_20: Retail Data Cooperative Guideline 21.1 The 'Consumer' shall have the right to object, on grounds relating to their particular situation, at any time to processing of 'shopping basket data' concerning them which is based on point (e) or (f) of Guideline 6.1, including consumer behavior analysis based on those provisions. The 'Retailer' shall no longer process the data unless the 'Retailer' demonstrates compelling legitimate grounds for the processing which override the interests, rights and freedoms of the 'Consumer' or for the establishment, exercise or defence of legal inventory management decisions. Guideline 6.1 Processing shall be lawful only if and to the extent that at least one of the following applies: e) processing is necessary for the performance of a task carried out in the public interest of 'market trend analysis' or in the exercise of business intelligence authority vested in the 'Retailer'; f) processing is necessary for the purposes of the legitimate interests pursued by the 'Retailer' or by a 'brand supplier' (e.g., 'precision marketing'), except where such interests are overridden by the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms of the 'Consumer' which require protection of 'shopping basket data'. That shall not apply to processing carried out by public authorities in the performance of their tasks.
usecase_21: Agricultural Data Space Terms of Use, Section 1798.105 (b) An 'agri-tech company' that collects 'soil and climate data' about 'farmers' shall disclose, pursuant to subparagraph (A) of paragraph (5) of subdivision (a) of Section 1798.130, the 'farmer’s' rights to request the deletion of the 'farmer’s' 'soil and climate data'. Section 1798.130 (a) an 'agri-tech company' shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy or policies and in any 'California Agricultural Data Space'-specific description of participants’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'farmer’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'farmer' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
usecase_22: Health Research Data Platform Policy, Section 1798.105 (b) A 'biotech company' that collects 'genetic sequence information' about 'research participants' shall disclose, pursuant to Section 1798.130 (a)(5)(A), the 'research participant’s' rights to request the deletion of their 'genetic sequence information'. Section 1798.130 (a) a 'biotech company' shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy and in any 'California Health Data Sharing Initiative'-specific description of participants’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'research participant’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'research participant' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
usecase_23: Smart Transportation Data Market Rules, Section 1798.105 (b) A 'navigation service provider' that collects 'vehicle location data' about 'drivers' shall disclose, pursuant to Section 1798.130 (a)(5)(A), the 'driver’s' rights to request the deletion of their 'vehicle location data'. Section 1798.130 (a) a 'navigation service provider' shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy and in any 'California Mobility Data Specification'-specific description of consumers’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'driver’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'driver' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
usecase_24: Online Education Platform User Agreement, Section 1798.105 (b) An 'ed-tech company' that collects 'learning progress data' about 'students' shall disclose, pursuant to Section 1798.130 (a)(5)(A), the 'student’s' rights to request the deletion of their 'learning progress data'. Section 1798.130 (a) an 'ed-tech company' shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy and in any 'California Student Privacy Protection'-specific description of consumers’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'student’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'student' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
usecase_25: Energy Consumption Data Sharing Policy, Section 1798.105 (b) A 'utility company' that collects 'smart meter data' about 'household users' shall disclose, pursuant to Section 1798.130 (a)(5)(A), the 'household user’s' rights to request the deletion of their 'smart meter data'. Section 1798.130 (a) a 'utility company' shall: (5) Disclose the following information in its online privacy policy or policies if the business has an online privacy policy and in any 'California Energy Data Privacy'-specific description of consumers’ privacy rights, or if the business does not maintain those policies, on its Internet Web site, and update that information at least once every 12 months: (A) A description of a 'household user’s' rights, which shall explicitly inform a 'household user' that they have the following rights, and provide one or more designated methods for submitting requests: Right to Know, Right to Access, Right to Opt-Out of Sale/Sharing.
usecase_26: Ad-Tech Data Market Rules, Section 1798.120 (a) A 'user' shall have the right, at any time, to direct a 'data broker' that sells the 'user’s' 'browsing history data' to third parties not to sell the 'user’s' 'browsing history data'. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), a 'data broker' shall not sell the 'browsing history data' of 'users' if the 'data broker' has actual knowledge that the 'user' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'user', in the case of 'users' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'user’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'users' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'user’s' 'browsing history data'. A 'data broker' that willfully disregards the 'user’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'user’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in'.
usecase_27: Gaming Platform User Data Policy, Section 1798.120 (a) A 'player' shall have the right, at any time, to direct a 'game publisher' that sells the 'player’s' 'in-game behavior data' to third parties not to sell the 'player’s' 'in-game behavior data'. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), a 'game publisher' shall not sell the 'in-game behavior data' of 'players' if the 'game publisher' has actual knowledge that the 'player' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'player', in the case of 'players' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'player’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'players' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'player’s' 'in-game behavior data'. A 'game publisher' that willfully disregards the 'player’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'player’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in'.
usecase_28: Social Media Data Sharing Agreement, Section 1798.120 (a) A 'registered user' shall have the right, at any time, to direct a 'platform operator' that sells the 'registered user’s' 'social graph data' to third parties not to sell the 'registered user’s' 'social graph data'. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), a 'platform operator' shall not sell the 'social graph data' of 'registered users' if the 'platform operator' has actual knowledge that the 'registered user' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'registered user', in the case of 'registered users' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'registered user’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'registered users' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'registered user’s' 'social graph data'. A 'platform operator' that willfully disregards the 'registered user’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'registered user’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in'.
usecase_29: Telecommunications Customer Data Management Regulation, Section 1798.120 (a) A 'subscriber' shall have the right, at any time, to direct a 'telecom operator' that sells the 'subscriber’s' 'call location data' to third parties not to sell the 'subscriber’s' 'call location data'. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), a 'telecom operator' shall not sell the 'call location data' of 'subscribers' if the 'telecom operator' has actual knowledge that the 'subscriber' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'subscriber', in the case of 'subscribers' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'subscriber’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'subscribers' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'subscriber’s' 'call location data'. A 'telecom operator' that willfully disregards the 'subscriber’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'subscriber’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in'.
usecase_30: Loyalty Program Data Use Policy, Section 1798.120 (a) A 'member' shall have the right, at any time, to direct a 'retail alliance' that sells the 'member’s' 'loyalty points data' to third parties not to sell the 'member’s' 'loyalty points data'. This right may be referred to as the right to opt out. (d) Notwithstanding subdivision (a), a 'retail alliance' shall not sell the 'loyalty points data' of 'members' if the 'retail alliance' has actual knowledge that the 'member' is less than 16 years of age, unless the 'member', in the case of 'members' between 13 and 16 years of age, or the 'member’s' parent or guardian, in the case of 'members' who are less than 13 years of age, has affirmatively authorized the sale of the 'member’s' 'loyalty points data'. A 'retail alliance' that willfully disregards the 'member’s' age shall be deemed to have had actual knowledge of the 'member’s' age. This right may be referred to as the 'right to opt in'.
usecase_31: Industrial Data Space Access Rules, Article 45 'Equipment owners' have the right to access and copy their 'equipment operational data' from the 'platform operator', except under circumstances specified in Article 18 of these rules. When an 'equipment owner' requests to access or copy their 'equipment operational data', the 'platform operator' shall provide it promptly. If an 'equipment owner' requests the transfer of their 'equipment operational data' to a designated 'third-party service provider', the 'platform operator' shall provide a means for transfer, provided it meets the conditions set by the 'National Industrial Data Committee'. Article 18 If the 'platform operator' is processing 'equipment operational data' that is subject to confidentiality requirements under law or administrative regulations (such as trade secrets) or for which notification is not required, it may refrain from informing the 'equipment owner' of the matters specified in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
usecase_32: Connected Vehicle Data Management Measures, Article 45 'Vehicle owners' have the right to access and copy their 'vehicle driving behavior data' from the 'automaker', except under circumstances specified in Article 18 of these measures. When a 'vehicle owner' requests to access or copy their 'vehicle driving behavior data', the 'automaker' shall provide it promptly. If a 'vehicle owner' requests the transfer of their 'vehicle driving behavior data' to a designated 'insurance company', the 'automaker' shall provide a means for transfer, provided it meets the conditions set by the 'National Connected Vehicle Data Center'. Article 18 If the 'automaker' is processing 'vehicle driving behavior data' that is subject to confidentiality requirements under law or administrative regulations (such as sensitive information in accident investigations) or for which notification is not required, it may refrain from informing the 'vehicle owner' of the matters specified in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
usecase_33: Health Record Data Sharing Guidelines, Article 45 'Patients' have the right to access and copy their 'electronic health records' from the 'hospital', except under circumstances specified in Article 18 of these guidelines. When a 'patient' requests to access or copy their 'electronic health records', the 'hospital' shall provide them promptly. If a 'patient' requests the transfer of their 'electronic health records' to another designated 'healthcare institution', the 'hospital' shall provide a means for transfer, provided it meets the conditions set by the 'National Health Information Office'. Article 18 If the 'hospital' is processing 'electronic health records' that are subject to confidentiality requirements under law or administrative regulations (such as mental health records) or for which notification is not required, it may refrain from informing the 'patient' of the matters specified in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
usecase_34: Smart Logistics Platform Data Policy, Article 45 'Cargo owners' have the right to access and copy their 'cargo transport status data' from the 'platform operator', except under circumstances specified in Article 18 of this policy. When a 'cargo owner' requests to access or copy their 'cargo transport status data', the 'platform operator' shall provide it promptly. If a 'cargo owner' requests the transfer of their 'cargo transport status data' to a designated 'warehouse service provider', the 'platform operator' shall provide a means for transfer, provided it meets the conditions set by the 'National Logistics Information Center'. Article 18 If the 'platform operator' is processing 'cargo transport status data' that is subject to confidentiality requirements under law or administrative regulations (such as high-value cargo information) or for which notification is not required, it may refrain from informing the 'cargo owner' of the matters specified in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
usecase_35: Financial Credit Information Management Regulations, Article 45 'Individuals' have the right to access and copy their 'credit reports' from the 'credit reporting agency', except under circumstances specified in Article 18 of these regulations. When an 'individual' requests to access or copy their 'credit report', the 'credit reporting agency' shall provide it promptly. If an 'individual' requests the transfer of their 'credit report' to another designated 'lending institution', the 'credit reporting agency' shall provide a means for transfer, provided it meets the conditions set by the 'National Credit Regulatory Authority'. Article 18 If the 'credit reporting agency' is processing 'credit reports' that are subject to confidentiality requirements under law or administrative regulations (such as national security reviews) or for which notification is not required, it may refrain from informing the 'individual' of the matters specified in the first paragraph of the preceding article.
usecase_36: Catena-X Automotive Data Space Cross-Border Rules, Article 53 'Component suppliers' located 'outside the EU' as defined in Article 3, paragraph 2 of these rules, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative within the 'Catena-X China Region' to handle data protection-related affairs, and shall submit the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the 'Data Space Management Committee'. Article 3 Activities involving the processing of 'battery lifecycle data' from vehicles within 'China' that are conducted 'outside the EU' shall also be subject to these rules if one of the following conditions is met: (2) The analysis or assessment of the behavior of 'vehicle owners' within the territory.
usecase_37: Global Clinical Trial Data Sharing Platform Charter, Article 53 'Research sub-centers' located 'outside the platform network' as defined in Article 3, paragraph 2 of this charter, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative at the 'Platform's China Node' to handle data protection-related affairs, and shall submit the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the 'Ethics Review Board'. Article 3 Activities involving the processing of 'genomic data' from participants within 'China' that are conducted 'outside the platform network' shall also be subject to this charter if one of the following conditions is met: (2) The analysis or assessment of the health status of 'patients' within the territory.
usecase_38: International E-commerce Logistics Alliance Data Policy, Article 53 'Overseas warehouse service providers' located 'outside the Alliance' as defined in Article 3, paragraph 2 of this policy, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative within the 'Alliance's China Region' to handle data protection-related affairs, and shall submit the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the 'Alliance Council'. Article 3 Activities involving the processing of 'cross-border parcel tracking data' of consumers within 'China' that are conducted 'outside the Alliance' shall also be subject to this policy if one of the following conditions is met: (2) The analysis or assessment of the purchasing behavior of 'consumers' within the territory.
usecase_39: Transnational Carbon Emissions Monitoring Network Protocol, Article 53 'Data analysis institutions' located 'outside the network coverage area' as defined in Article 3, paragraph 2 of this protocol, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative within the 'Network's China Monitoring Zone' to handle data protection-related affairs, and shall submit the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the 'Protocol Supervisory Group'. Article 3 Activities involving the processing of 'carbon emissions data' of enterprises within 'China' that are conducted 'outside the network coverage area' shall also be subject to this protocol if one of the following conditions is met: (2) The analysis or assessment of the environmental compliance behavior of 'enterprises' within the territory.
usecase_40: Global Financial Anti-Money Laundering Data Exchange Framework, Article 53 'Partner financial institutions' located 'outside the Framework' as defined in Article 3, paragraph 2 of this framework, shall establish a dedicated entity or appoint a representative within the 'Framework's China Region' to handle data protection-related affairs, and shall submit the name of the entity or the name and contact information of the representative to the 'Framework Executive Committee'. Article 3 Activities involving the processing of 'large-value transaction data' of customers within 'China' that are conducted 'outside the Framework' shall also be subject to this framework if one of the following conditions is met: (2) The analysis or assessment of the fund flow behavior of 'customers' within the territory.
usecase_41: Implementing Rules of the Data Security Law in Catena-X, Article 46 Any party that provides 'critical component design schematics' overseas in violation of Article 31 of these rules shall be ordered to rectify by the 'industry competent authority', given a warning, and may be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan; the 'Data Security Officer' and other directly responsible personnel may be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. In severe cases, the fine shall be not less than 1 million yuan but not more than 10 million yuan, and the party may be ordered to suspend relevant business, cease operations for rectification, or have its 'data processing license' revoked; the 'Data Security Officer' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan. Article 31 The cross-border security management of 'critical component design schematics' collected and generated by 'OEMs', as operators of critical information infrastructure, during their operations within the 'territory of China' shall be governed by the provisions of the 'Cybersecurity Law of the People's Republic of China'; the measures for the cross-border security management of 'critical component design schematics' collected and generated by other 'suppliers' during their operations within the 'territory of China' shall be formulated by the 'national cyberspace administration' in conjunction with the 'State Council's industrial and information technology department'.
usecase_42: Implementing Rules of the Data Security Law in the National Gene Bank, Article 46 Any party that provides 'human genetic resource information' overseas in violation of Article 31 of these rules shall be ordered to rectify by the 'science and technology competent authority', given a warning, and may be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan; the 'Project Leader' and other directly responsible personnel may be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. In severe cases, the fine shall be not less than 1 million yuan but not more than 10 million yuan, and the party may be ordered to suspend relevant research, cease operations for rectification, or have its 'research permit' revoked; the 'Project Leader' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan. Article 31 The cross-border security management of 'human genetic resource information' collected and generated by the 'National Gene Bank', as an operator of critical information infrastructure, during its operations within the 'territory of China' shall be governed by the provisions of the 'Cybersecurity Law of the People's Republic of China'; the measures for the cross-border security management of 'human genetic resource information' collected and generated by other 'research institutions' during their operations within the 'territory of China' shall be formulated by the 'national cyberspace administration' in conjunction with the 'State Council's health department'.
usecase_43: Implementing Rules of the Data Security Law in the State Grid, Article 46 Any party that provides 'critical power grid operational data' overseas in violation of Article 31 of these rules shall be ordered to rectify by the 'energy competent authority', given a warning, and may be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan; the 'Security Supervisor' and other directly responsible personnel may be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. In severe cases, the fine shall be not less than 1 million yuan but not more than 10 million yuan, and the party may be ordered to suspend relevant business, cease operations for rectification, or have its 'operating license' revoked; the 'Security Supervisor' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan. Article 31 The cross-border security management of 'critical power grid operational data' collected and generated by the 'State Grid Corporation of China', as an operator of critical information infrastructure, during its operations within the 'territory of China' shall be governed by the provisions of the 'Cybersecurity Law of the People's Republic of China'; the measures for the cross-border security management of 'critical power grid operational data' collected and generated by other 'power generation enterprises' during their operations within the 'territory of China' shall be formulated by the 'national cyberspace administration' in conjunction with the 'State Council's energy department'.
usecase_44: Implementing Rules of the Data Security Law in Financial Information Systems, Article 46 Any party that provides 'core financial transaction data' overseas in violation of Article 31 of these rules shall be ordered to rectify by the 'financial regulatory authority', given a warning, and may be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan; the 'Compliance Officer' and other directly responsible personnel may be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. In severe cases, the fine shall be not less than 1 million yuan but not more than 10 million yuan, and the party may be ordered to suspend relevant business, cease operations for rectification, or have its 'financial license' revoked; the 'Compliance Officer' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan. Article 31 The cross-border security management of 'core financial transaction data' collected and generated by the operator of the 'Central Clearing System' during its operations within the 'territory of China' shall be governed by the provisions of the 'Cybersecurity Law of the People's Republic of China'; the measures for the cross-border security management of 'core financial transaction data' collected and generated by other 'commercial banks' during their operations within the 'territory of China' shall be formulated by the 'national cyberspace administration' in conjunction with the 'People's Bank of China'.
usecase_45: Implementing Rules of the Data Security Law in Civil Aviation Information Systems, Article 46 Any party that provides 'passenger name record data' overseas in violation of Article 31 of these rules shall be ordered to rectify by the 'civil aviation competent authority', given a warning, and may be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan; the 'Information Supervisor' and other directly responsible personnel may be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. In severe cases, the fine shall be not less than 1 million yuan but not more than 10 million yuan, and the party may be ordered to suspend relevant business, cease operations for rectification, or have its 'operating permit' revoked; the 'Information Supervisor' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 100,000 yuan but not more than 1 million yuan. Article 31 The cross-border security management of 'passenger name record data' collected and generated by 'TravelSky Technology Limited', as an operator of critical information infrastructure, during its operations within the 'territory of China' shall be governed by the provisions of the 'Cybersecurity Law of the People's Republic of China'; the measures for the cross-border security management of 'passenger name record data' collected and generated by other 'airlines' during their operations within the 'territory of China' shall be formulated by the 'national cyberspace administration' in conjunction with the 'State Council's transport department'.
usecase_46: Industrial Data Space Management Regulations, Article 48 Any party that refuses to cooperate with data retrieval for a 'production safety accident investigation' in violation of Article 35 of these regulations shall be ordered to rectify by the 'industry competent authority', given a warning, and fined not less than 50,000 yuan but not more than 500,000 yuan; the 'Factory Manager' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. Article 35 When 'work safety supervision and administration departments' or 'state security organs' need to retrieve 'historical equipment operational data' for the purpose of lawfully maintaining 'production safety' or investigating 'safety liability accidents', they shall do so in accordance with relevant state regulations, following strict approval procedures, and relevant 'enterprises' and 'individuals' shall cooperate.
usecase_47: Financial Data Sharing Platform Rules, Article 48 Any party that refuses to cooperate with data retrieval for an 'anti-money laundering investigation' in violation of Article 35 of these rules shall be ordered to rectify by the 'financial regulatory authority', given a warning, and fined not less than 50,000 yuan but not more than 500,000 yuan; the 'Chief Compliance Officer' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. Article 35 When 'public security organs' or 'state security organs' need to retrieve 'suspicious transaction reports' for the purpose of lawfully maintaining 'financial security' or investigating 'financial crimes', they shall do so in accordance with relevant state regulations, following strict approval procedures, and relevant 'financial institutions' and 'individuals' shall cooperate.
usecase_48: Connected Vehicle Data Security Standards, Article 48 Any party that refuses to cooperate with data retrieval for a 'traffic accident in-depth analysis' in violation of Article 35 of these standards shall be ordered to rectify by the 'transportation management department', given a warning, and fined not less than 50,000 yuan but not more than 500,000 yuan; the 'Vehicle Safety Supervisor' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. Article 35 When 'public security organs' or 'state security organs' need to retrieve 'vehicle event data recorder (EDR) data' for the purpose of lawfully maintaining 'public transport safety' or investigating 'hit-and-run cases', they shall do so in accordance with relevant state regulations, following strict approval procedures, and relevant 'automakers' and 'vehicle owners' shall cooperate.
usecase_49: Online Platform Content Management Provisions, Article 48 Any party that refuses to cooperate with data retrieval for 'tracing the source of online rumors' in violation of Article 35 of these provisions shall be ordered to rectify by the 'cyberspace content competent authority', given a warning, and fined not less than 50,000 yuan but not more than 500,000 yuan; the 'Platform Content Moderation Supervisor' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. Article 35 When 'public security organs' or 'state security organs' need to retrieve 'user posting logs' for the purpose of lawfully maintaining 'national political security' or investigating crimes of 'spreading violent and terrorist information', they shall do so in accordance with relevant state regulations, following strict approval procedures, and relevant 'platform operators' and 'users' shall cooperate.
usecase_50: Environmental Protection Data Sharing Measures, Article 48 Any party that refuses to cooperate with data retrieval for 'tracking pollution sources' in violation of Article 35 of these measures shall be ordered to rectify by the 'ecological and environmental competent authority', given a warning, and fined not less than 50,000 yuan but not more than 500,000 yuan; the 'Environmental Protection Officer' and other directly responsible personnel shall be fined not less than 10,000 yuan but not more than 100,000 yuan. Article 35 When 'public security organs' or 'state security organs' need to retrieve 'enterprise pollution monitoring data' for the purpose of lawfully maintaining 'national ecological security' or investigating crimes of 'illegal discharge of pollutants', they shall do so in accordance with relevant state regulations, following strict approval procedures, and relevant 'polluting entities' and 'individuals' shall cooperate.
